awd_titl_txt: REU Site: CAAR: Combinatorics, Algorithms, and AI Applied to Real Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
This renewal REU Site program will recruit 10 undergraduate students to come to the University of Maryland at College Park where they will work for 10 weeks on team research projects with mentors. The students will be offered a variety of research projects and will also be given a strong voice in the creation of their own projects. Several will develop new techniques and analyses of machine learning (ML) systems, which use probability and statistics to find patterns in data. Others will use cryptography to build secure systems. Research projects in following topical areas will be offered: Cryptography and Security; Fair Allocation; Trustworthy Machine Learning; and Neural Networks and Finance. These projects broadly focus on combining theory and practice and students attending the program will leave it with the ability to look at a real world problem and apply theoretical techniques to solving it. 
There will be a special effort to recruit students in the program from non-research-focused schools and from traditionally underrepresented groups. The PIs plan several recruiting trips (in person or on zoom) to such schools to attract such students.  This program will give many of the students a chance to do research, which they otherwise would not have. This program will prepare all of the students for graduate school. Social activities include trips, hikes, panel discussions about professional development, and other planned interactions with other REU students, current graduate students, and faculty

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
REU-CAAR (Research Experience for Undergraduates-Combinatorics, Algorithms, and AI for Real Problems)is a program whereby students come to theUniversity of Maryland Campus for 10 weeks over the summerand work on computer science projects.
Students apply for the program. We've had over 300applicants every year and took between 15 and 20.
The projects were a mix of practical and theoretical.The practical projects were on cryptography (which ishelpful for security), algorithms (which is helpful to getthe programs you use to run faster), AI (which is becomingmore and more part of our lives, andquantum computing (which will be important in the long term).


1) Five projects were on quantum computing. Even though quantumcomputing is in its infancy, the potential is enormous.  Hence it isgood to see what is possible theoretically so that when itbecomes a reality, we will be ready. Three papers came out of this work.Two were on error correction which is an important component to makingquantum computers work. One was on how to verify that a quantumcomputation is correct, which will be needed once quantum computers are build.


2) Two of the projects was on crypto. Most current crypto systemsare based on problems in number theory (e.g, factoring) being hard.There has been much research on getting crypto systems that arebased on other problems being hard. There are two reasons for this:(a) Quantum computers or very clever mathematics may makefactoring easy, (b) its good to not put all our eggs in one basket.In this project students looked at crypto systems based onlattice problems that are thought to be hard.The groups involved with these project produced a software packagewhich will be helpful to test the security of proposed systems.

3) Three of the projects were on AI.


a) Wikipedia-Translation:  When Wikipedia gets translated itsometimes makes mistakes. What kind? Why?The group has a paper about howpredicting mistakes in machine-generated translations of Wikipedia.Figuring out where translation systems fail will help to make them better.A paper came out of these projects.

 


b) Question-Answer Systems. Current AI-Question-Answer systems do well whenthe question is given as text, but not when its given visually or by sound.This project examined which questions asked in which ways are hardfor AI-Question-Answer systems to answer.Figuring out where question-answer systems fail will help to make them better.


c) Farmers often have to know when to plant which crops. A further complication isthat if they all plant the same crop, the market could be flooded and the pricedrops.  In this project advanced math, and computer programs, are used tohelp farmers. Two papers and a computer package was written for this.


4) Two of the projects were on Parallel Computing.If one computer can solve a problem in 1 minute,then the hope is that 2 computers working together can solvethat problem in 30 seconds. Alas, life is not that simple.This project looked at real parallel systems and made themrun fast on real problems involving search.


5) There were other projects that were more on the theory side.They may help computing in the long run.


In addition to the projects, students got to see what research was like which will inform them about what graduate school is like.Hence their decision about going to graduate school or not will bebetter informed.
